text:
The big concern for me about crypto betting is if HMRC decide to randomly interpret tax rules differently....at the moment income tax isn't (or shouldn't be an issue), however I'm not sure its clear how you calculate CGT on any winnings if you previously have offsetting losses.

So consider the following example:

day 1: You buy 1 BTC @ 20k, you back runner x and lose it all
day 2: You buy 1 BTC @ 22k, you back runner y and win, you now have 1.5 BTC in your account
day 3: BTC rallies to 60k and you decide to cash out completely, incurring a CGT bill due to creating a taxable event

Ignoring the timescale and whether you'd actually do the above in reality, how do you calculate your buy in price, as how can you be sure HMRC will allow you to write off that lost 1 BTC @ 20k?

elements.text:

So consider the following example:

day 1: You buy 1 BTC @ 20k, you back runner x and lose it all
day 2: You buy 1 BTC @ 22k, you back runner y and win, you now have 1.5 BTC in your account
day 3: BTC rallies to 60k and you decide to cash out completely, incurring a CGT bill due to creating a taxable event

Ignoring the timescale and whether you'd actually do the above in reality, how do you calculate your buy in price, as how can you be sure HMRC will allow you to write off that lost 1 BTC @ 20k?

text: Yeah as a UK resident the tax would kill it. Assuming that you could replicate your strategies on a decentralised exchange such that your profits were retained (incredibly unlikely) you would then have to pay tax on your winnings. Irrelevent what kind of coin/token was used to perform the actual wagering, as far as UK rules go (when I last checked), every trade of any token is a taxable event. Would be much simpler if it were only crypto to fiat conversions that were taxable but that is not how HMRC currently view it. It is hard enough to make money as it is never mind having your winnings taxed too! I love the concept of a decentralised exchange in theory as it would enable us to escape the nanny state affordability nonsense that may or may not happen. In practice though I can't see how it would work.

It is hard enough to make money as it is never mind having your winnings taxed too! text: Another aspect that makes it unattractive is that if it is TRULY decentralised then there must be a consensus mechanism where the result can be established truthfully and be safe from bad actors. Augur used to have the REP token for this so that holders would "vote" to verify settlement results but I have no idea if this is still the case as I have not looked at it for ages. As others have said though, its hard enough to drive punters to the exchange anyway through better prices. My father is a lifelong recreational punter and is far from stupid, but he still doesn't really "get" the exchange model.

text:
Automated trading strategies - actually any kind of trading - needs two parties to agree on the price

Who is going to think that these automated trading strategies are posting prices they want to match with? Either it's dumb money that's price insensitive, it's other sharks who think the price is wrong or it's people with different incentives - ie they want to lay off some risk and are happy to pay the margin to do so

With the crypto angle you are heavily disincentivising the laying off of risk. No regulated bookmaker or sports entity is going to be doing this on a black/grey market exchange

Sharks eating sharks does not lead to sustainable liquidity

So now you have pretty much all of the same problems that Betfair has attracting dumb liquidity - and they are big problems - and crypto doesn't really help you solve them. Punters find it hard enough to understand the exchange model and now you want them to educate themselves around crypto on boarding etc? If you want to remain black market then you have some advantage but it's not something I would personally risk jail time for

So now you have pretty much all of the same problems that Betfair has attracting dumb liquidity - and they are big problems - and crypto doesn't really help you solve them. Punters find it hard enough to understand the exchange model and now you want them to educate themselves around crypto on boarding etc? If you want to remain black market then you have some advantage but it's not something I would personally risk jail time for

text: It is not about stablecoins though is it. I dabbled with an NFT based "game" and it was an absolute nightmare keeping records. As it happens, I never declared anything because I ultimately lost money on it overall but I made sure I kept all the records in case HMRC come knocking in future. It was a real grind and there is no way I would bother doing the same to place bets on a decentralised exchange. If HMRC had the attitude they used to (that all crypto transactions were essentially "gambling") it would be OK but as of now I could never be bothered to use a DEX for betting.

text:
It seems sensible to refer to examples of what others in crypto have done, since my own project is still under construction.

So one of the advantages of crypto is that it really makes the transfer of value very easy and also makes interacting with multiple programs or applications more straightforward. For example, the order book based dex Serum doesn't have an official UI anymore. They simply have a UI hoster fee, where of any transaction fees that are obtained from a trade, a portion automatically get sent to the UI hoster. This is just one example of ways you can change how the structure of businessses work with crypto.

text:
Yes...but the problem comes if its hundreds of transactions over a year...obviously if its a small number its not a problem, but we're talking about automated betting here, so realistically its likely to be a lot of transactions.

Now admittedly not all need to involve converting to Fiat, so you can keep it down to some degree, but its still an unnecessary headache!

text: But in this context the Fx is an issue too...its only non-taxable if its for a legitimate purchase (e.g. holiday money, an overseas property, even a boat would be fine)...but if you're transfering GBP to USD with the intent to buy crypto then (my interpretation) is that in that scenario even the GBPUSD becomes a taxable event (which it wouldn't under normal circumstances e.g. going on holiday)

text:
If you were a high net worth individual and you were profitable then it may be a tenuous case (thats just me speculating)...for 99% of people it would be considered 'holiday spend' which is a legitimate use as per HMRC guidelines.

But I don't think you can treat a Casino and crypto in the same way...HMRC's issue would be that your GBP was converted to crypto via USD, not that you were betting in USD...so if you say transfer to a USD denominated 'fiat' betting account there's no issue. Its a strict interpretation of the rules that suggests there could be one, because HMRC doesn't treat crypto as a currency or gambling (it's initial stance was different).

That's just my take of course...I may well be wrong...but I'm not going to take on HMRC to find out!!!

text: I have crypto on both. For security in wallets I have a hardware wallet. For security on exchanges I try to only use reputable exchanges that I trust and try not to store too much crypto on them for an extended period or to store more than I'm willing to lose. To be fair the same principles apply to interacting with onchain defi programs. There's always a chance that programs will be hacked. Just as there is a risk with centralized exchanges.

elements.text: I have crypto on both. For security in wallets I have a hardware wallet. For security on exchanges I try to only use reputable exchanges that I trust and try not to store too much crypto on them for an extended period or to store more than I'm willing to lose. To be fair the same principles apply to interacting with onchain defi programs. There's always a chance that programs will be hacked. Just as there is a risk with centralized exchanges.

text:
HMRC consider crypto an asset and have published lots of manuals about crypto trading. imho it could work out like this since assets have monetary value and can therefore be treated the same as money ...

day1: you lost an asset with value 20k by betting using your asset as the stake. Betting is not taxable so no impact for income tax and not allowable for CGT
day2: you won 0.5 bitcoin by betting - no tax issues arise. However you have now gained by betting a capital asset worth 11k at that time. This would become the initial market value for any future disposal of the asset. You could cash it out at that time for 11k and no tax issues. By leaving it in you are effectively "buying" 0.5bc for 11k - think that's the way they would construe it.
day3: you sell your holdings for 90k. You have made capital gains of (60-22) for the original bc purchase and (30-11) as the capital gain on the 0.5 bc you won. So CGT arises on 57k

elements.text:

day2: you won 0.5 bitcoin by betting - no tax issues arise. However you have now gained by betting a capital asset worth 11k at that time. This would become the initial market value for any future disposal of the asset. You could cash it out at that time for 11k and no tax issues. By leaving it in you are effectively "buying" 0.5bc for 11k - think that's the way they would construe it.
day3: you sell your holdings for 90k. You have made capital gains of (60-22) for the original bc purchase and (30-11) as the capital gain on the 0.5 bc you won. So CGT arises on 57k

text:
Agreedif they agree you've lost the asset, which I think is a grey area specific to crypto.

If you lose your keys for example HMRC a does not accept this as a loss you can write off and there is a school of thought (which may be wrong of course) that says by spending your crypto on a service (gambling in this case) it was spent rather than lost and this could change things

Not saying that's correct, I'm just the paranoid type and was reading an article that highlighted the above scenario hence my concern (they conceded it's untested and unlikely too).

text:
Yeah, that was essentially the exact conclusion of the article tbh, my concern was simply until this is test, who's to say HMRC won't jump on that hypothetical risk...even if overturned later in court its still a headache.

It would be nice if they could come up with some new (and ideally better thought out) concrete guidelines for crypto taxes!
